docs.snippet: The Custom House report of exports and imports at this port during June, issued yesterday by Collector Malone, covering countries and grand divisions, shows steadily increasing outward shipments over preceding months since the war began. While...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Custom House report of exports and imports at this port during June, issued yesterday by Collector Malone, covering countries and grand divisions, shows steadily increasing outward shipments over preceding months since the war began. While imports last month fell off about $6,500,000, compared with June, 1914, the drop in entries was not as pronounced as in other months of this year when compared with similar periods of 1914.

headline.main: SOME SHIFTS OF FOREIGN TRADE; Changes in Imports and Exports from This Port Shown by the June Figures.

docs.snippet: Speaking before the members of the New York State Automobile Association, gathered at Niagara Falls last week for their mid-year convention, Francis M. Hugo, Secretary of State, urged a closer affiliation of all motor clubs, pointing out that in this...
docs.lead_paragraph: Speaking before the members of the New York State Automobile Association, gathered at Niagara Falls last week for their mid-year convention, Francis M. Hugo, Secretary of State, urged a closer affiliation of all motor clubs, pointing out that in this way only can motorists achieve the greatest results in advancing the good roads movement.

headline.main: URGES CLUB CO-OPERATION.; Hugo Says Motorists Should Encourage Reciprocal Touring.

docs.snippet: LONDON, July 29. -- Carl Reinhard, a German, who has a residence in Richmond, England, was sentenced at Falmouth today to six months' imprisonment at hard labor for landing in England from the United States with a passport which, according to the...
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 29. -- Carl Reinhard, a German, who has a residence in Richmond, England, was sentenced at Falmouth today to six months' imprisonment at hard labor for landing in England from the United States with a passport which, according to the evidence, he admitted was forged.

headline.main: Six Months for Haying False Papers.; OUR PASSPORTS FORGED, SPY ADMITS

docs.abstract: tells of foreign contracts being filed in Pittsburgh

headline.main: PITTSBURGH'S WAR TRADE.; Foreign Contracts Totaling $100,000,000 Are Being Filled There.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Its patience exhausted, the United States Government has determined that the time has arrived when it must take action to restore order and constitutional authority in Mexico. A program to that end has been considered, but...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Its patience exhausted, the United States Government has determined that the time has arrived when it must take action to restore order and constitutional authority in Mexico. A program to that end has been considered, but before putting this into effect the Government will consult with the Republics of South and Central America, which will be asked to adhere to its purposes.
docs.abstract: U. S. Govt. calls Ambassadors of Argentina, Brazil, and Chile and Ministers of Bolivia, Urugjuay, and Guatemala to conference; support aimed at for, peace program, new Pres, in view, Iturbide hinted at; relief for Mexico City and guard of railways if necessary

headline.main: PRESIDENT SEEKS PAN-AMERICAN AID FOR MEXICO MOVE; Calls A B C Ambassadors and Three Ministers to a Conference. FIRST TO BE "INFORMAL" But Support of Other Latin Republics for Peace Program Is Aimed At. NEW PRESIDENT IN VIEW As Well as Immediate Relief for Mexico City and Guard of Railways if Necessary. PAN-AMERICAN AID FOR MEXICO MOVE

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON Aug. 3. -- The invitation of the United States to six Latin-American countries to have their diplomatic representatives confer with Secretary Lansing over the conditions in Mexico was extended more than a month ago. This significant fact...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON Aug. 3. -- The invitation of the United States to six Latin-American countries to have their diplomatic representatives confer with Secretary Lansing over the conditions in Mexico was extended more than a month ago. This significant fact was made known in an authoritative way at the State Department today.
docs.abstract: had been planned in June, details not revealed

headline.main: MEXICO CONCERT PLANNED IN JUNE; Six American Republics Informed a Month Ago of President's Purposes. PROGRAM ARRANGED THEN And Accepted in Principle by the Other Nations -- Details Not Revealed. MEXICO CITY WIRES CUT Bandits on Border Kill American Troopers and Wound Two Others -- Filibusters Caught. MEXICO CONCERT PLANNED IN JUNE

byline.original: Special to The New York Times
Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- On the principle of "All for one, one for all," the six Latin-American nations which have accepted the invitation of the United States to confer tomorrow on the Mexican situation will be asked to join this Government in the...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- On the principle of "All for one, one for all," the six Latin-American nations which have accepted the invitation of the United States to confer tomorrow on the Mexican situation will be asked to join this Government in the proposed effort to adjust conditions in Mexico.

headline.main: PLAN FINAL APPEAL TO MEXICAN CHIEFS; Will Be Framed at Today's Conference of Seven Republics in Washington. ALL NATIONS' VOICES EQUAL Carranza to Have One More Chance to Join Movement to Establish Strong Government. PLAN FINAL APPEAL TO MEXICAN CHIEFS
